title: David Walker's Appeal, edition 3
grace-desc: In the third edition of the Appeal, published in 1830, David Walker alluded to the Park Street Church incident.

title: Lecture Delivered at the Franklin Hall, Boston, September 21st, 1832. The Liberator, vol. 2, no. 46, 17 Nov. 1832
grace-desc: The Liberator published Maria Stewart's second public lecture in November of 1832.

title: Tremont Temple Baptist Church,
1846 Petition to Primary School Committee
grace-desc: In 1846, George Putnam and 85 other Black Bostonians petitioned the Primary School Committee to end school segregation.

title: Sketch of the Abiel Smith School, 1849
grace-desc: Since 1835, the Abiel Smith School had served as the city's only school for the children of Black families.

title: Lewis Hayden
grace-desc: Following his involvement with the Boston Vigilance Committee and his involvement in the desegregation of Boston schools, Lewis Hayden became one of the first Black representatives of the Massachusetts General Court.

title: Marshal's Posse with Burns Moving Down State Street
source: Stevens, Charles Emery. 1856. Anthony Burnsâ€¯: a History. Boston: John P. Jewett and Co.
grace-desc: This image of the aftermath of the Burns trial was published in Charles Emery Stevens's Anthony Burns: A History in 1856.

title: Anthony Burns Cartoon and Portrait
grace-desc: This cartoon from 1855 includes a portrait of Burns accompanied by sketches of key moments in his life.

title: "A Man Kidnapped!"
grace-desc: Abolitionists gathered in protest at Faneuil Hall in response to Burns's arrest.

title: Boston Vigilance Committee October 1850 Meeting
grace-desc: The expenses of the Boston Vigilance Committee in October 1850, following its reorganization.

title: Portrait of Ellen Craft in disguise
Portrait of William C. Nell
Authorized Agents of Freedom's Journal, Freedom's Journal, all volumes
grace-desc: Thomas Paul, along with David Walker, was a sales agent for Freedom's Journal in Massachusetts.

title: Boston Meeting on Freedom's Journal, Freedom's Journal, vol. no.
grace-desc: George B. Holmes spoke at a meeting of Black Bostonians on Freedom's Journal.

title: Address Delivered Before the African Grand Lodge, Boston, No. 459, June 24, 1828 by John T. Hilton
grace-desc: Addresses like the one John T Hilton gave to the African Lodge were often published in newspapers like Freedom's Journal.

title: Address Delivered Before the African Grand Lodge, Boston, No. 459, June 24, 1828 by John T. Hilton
grace-desc: Addresses like the one John T Hilton gave to the African Lodge were often published in newspapers like Freedom's Journal.

title: Address Delivered Before the African Grand Lodge, Boston, No. 459, June 24, 1828 by John T. Hilton
grace-desc: Addresses like the one John T Hilton gave to the African Lodge were often published in newspapers like Freedom's Journal.

title: Address, Delivered before the General Colored Association at Boston, by David Walker.
grace-desc: David Walker was closely involved with the MGCA, and one of his addresses to the organization was published in Freedom's Journal.

title: Advertisement for Walker's used clothing store, 1829, Freedom's Journal, all after vol. no.
grace-desc: David Walker's Used Clothing Store was advertised in Freedom's Journal.

title: Resolution to Support Freedom's Journal, Freedom's Journal, vol. no.
grace-desc: **Freedom's Journal

title: No Union With Slaveholders! Boston, Feb. 21, 1851: The Arrest--The Rescue--The Flight
grace-desc: Volume 21, no. 8 of the Liberator recounted the coordinated escape of Shadrach Minkins from the Boston Court House.

source: Boston Slave Riot, and Trial of Anthony Burns

title: Announcement of Anthony Burns's Arrest
source: Boston Slave Riot, and Trial of Anthony Burns
grace-desc: Featured in the 1854 report of Anthony Burns's capture, this ad announces his arrest and references the recently passed Kansas-Nebraska Act which repealed the Missouri Compromise.

title: Argument of Charles Sumner, Esq., Against the Constitutionality of Separate Colored Schools
grace-desc: This image features the title page of a publication of Charles Sumner's argument in Roberts v City of Boston.

source: Boston Slave Riot, and Trial of Anthony Burns
grace-desc: This paragraph from the 1854 report on Anthony Burns mentions Coffin Pitts as the owner of the 36 Brattle Street clothing store and as Burns's employer.

title: The Latimer and Great Massachusetts Petition
